title: Subdomain takeover ████████.mil
content:
Description:
The subdomain █████.mil is pointing to peosol-lg.███████., the domain ██████ is currently available for registration as can be seen at https://www.godaddy.com/nl-nl/domainsearch/find?domainToCheck=█████
Given the rules, residency of the US, of the us-tld I decided not to register the domain, also I do believe the output to be enough.
References
Impact
Using this vulnerability an attacker can:
host unwanted/malicious content under your domain
receive email on subdomains mentioned above
effectively execute cross-site scripting attacks
in some cases, steal cookie data
in some cases, trick password managers into filling passwords
System Host(s)
██████████.mil
Affected Product(s) and Version(s)
CVE Numbers
Steps to Reproduce
See the DIG output:
Code 632 Bytes
1√ martinvw@denali:~/src > dig █████.mil
2
3; <<>> DiG 9.10.6 <<>> ████.mil
4;; global options: +cmd
5;; Got answer:
6;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: NXDOMAIN, id: 44977
7;; flags: qr rd ra; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 1, AUTHORITY: 1, ADDITIONAL: 1
8
9;; OPT PSEUDOSECTION:
10; EDNS: version: 0, flags:; udp: 512
11;; QUESTION SECTION:
12;█████████.mil.			IN	A
13

15██████████.mil.		3600	IN	CNAME	peosol-lg.███.
16
17;; AUTHORITY SECTION:
18us.			900	IN	SOA	a.cctld.us. admin.tldns.godaddy. 1715345748 1800 300 604800 1800
19
20;; Query time: 166 msec
21;; SERVER: 8.8.8.8#53(8.8.8.8)
22;; WHEN: Fri May 10 15:06:32 CEST 2024
23;; MSG SIZE  rcvd: 148
And the GoDaddy page: https://www.godaddy.com/nl-nl/domainsearch/find?domainToCheck=███

Suggested Mitigation/Remediation Actions
Remove CNAME record █████████.mil
steps: Check the DNS records of the subdomain █████.mil using a tool like dig to see if it points to an external domain.
Verify if the pointed domain (peosol-lg.███████.) is available for registration by checking on a domain registrar like GoDaddy.
vuln_description: The subdomain █████.mil is pointing to an external domain (peosol-lg.███████.) that is available for registration. This creates a subdomain takeover vulnerability where an attacker could register the domain and host malicious content, receive emails, execute cross-site scripting attacks, steal cookie data, or trick password managers.
reason: The vulnerability involves straightforward DNS checks and domain availability verification, with no complex interactions or novel logic required.

authnz_metadata.reasoning: The reported subdomain takeover vulnerability stems from DNS misconfiguration and domain registration availability, not from flawed authentication/authorization mechanisms within an application. The detection methodologies focus on session manipulation and resource ID testing within application workflows, while this vulnerability exists at the infrastructure level where DNS records point to an unclaimed third-party domain. No user session manipulation or authorization boundary testing within application logic would surface this issue.
